-Goal-
Given a text document that is potentially relevant to this activity and a list of entity types, identify all entities of those types from the text and all relationships among the identified entities.
Use English as output language.

-Steps-
1. Identify all entities. For each identified entity, extract the following information:
- entity_name: Name of the entity, use same language as input text. If English, capitalized the name.
- entity_type: One of the following types: [organization,person,geo,event,category]
- entity_description: Comprehensive description of the entity's attributes and activities
Format each entity as ("entity"<|><entity_name><|><entity_type><|><entity_description>)

2. From the entities identified in step 1, identify all pairs of (source_entity, target_entity) that are *clearly related* to each other.
For each pair of related entities, extract the following information:
- source_entity: name of the source entity, as identified in step 1
- target_entity: name of the target entity, as identified in step 1
- relationship_description: explanation as to why you think the source entity and the target entity are related to each other
- relationship_strength: a numeric score indicating strength of the relationship between the source entity and target entity
- relationship_keywords: one or more high-level key words that summarize the overarching nature of the relationship, focusing on concepts or themes rather than specific details
Format each relationship as ("relationship"<|><source_entity><|><target_entity><|><relationship_description><|><relationship_keywords><|><relationship_strength>)

3. Identify high-level key words that summarize the main concepts, themes, or topics of the entire text. These should capture the overarching ideas present in the document.
Format the content-level key words as ("content_keywords"<|><high_level_keywords>)

4. Return output in English as a single list of all the entities and relationships identified in steps 1 and 2. Use **##** as the list delimiter.

5. When finished, output <|COMPLETE|>

The underlying dismissal earlier seemed to falter, replaced by a glimpse of reluctant respect for the gravity of what lay in their hands. Jordan looked up, and for a fleeting heartbeat, their eyes locked with Taylor's, a wordless clash of wills softening into an uneasy truce.

It was a small transformation, barely perceptible, but one that Alex noted with an inward nod. They had all been brought here by different paths

Casing tally showing the length of each section of casing used and the depth-from-surface of
each casing joint.

Weatherford Sure-Shot tools), copies of the targets should be provided.

[{"role": "user", "content": "-Goal-
Given a text document that is potentially relevant to this activity and a list of entity types, identify all entities of those types from the text and all relationships among the identified entities.
Use English as output language.

-Steps-
1. Identify all entities. For each identified entity, extract the following information:
- entity_name: Name of the entity, use same language as input text. If English, capitalized the name.
- entity_type: One of the following types: [organization,person,geo,event,category]
- entity_description: Comprehensive description of the entity's attributes and activities
Format each entity as ("entity"<|><entity_name><|><entity_type><|><entity_description>)

2. From the entities identified in step 1, identify all pairs of (source_entity, target_entity) that are *clearly related* to each other.
For each pair of related entities, extract the following information:
- source_entity: name of the source entity, as identified in step 1
- target_entity: name of the target entity, as identified in step 1
- relationship_description: explanation as to why you think the source entity and the target entity are related to each other
- relationship_strength: a numeric score indicating strength of the relationship between the source entity and target entity
- relationship_keywords: one or more high-level key words that summarize the overarching nature of the relationship, focusing on concepts or themes rather than specific details
Format each relationship as ("relationship"<|><source_entity><|><target_entity><|><relationship_description><|><relationship_keywords><|><relationship_strength>)

3. Identify high-level key words that summarize the main concepts, themes, or topics of the entire text. These should capture the overarching ideas present in the document.
Format the content-level key words as ("content_keywords"<|><high_level_keywords>)

4. Return output in English as a single list of all the entities and relationships identified in steps 1 and 2. Use **##** as the list delimiter.

5. When finished, output <|COMPLETE|>

Text: preferred casing material is corrosion-resistant stainless-steel or similar material provides
corrosion protection. The casing minimum wall thickness shall be 6.2 cm (¼ inch). The casing
must be round, straight, free of irregularities and seamless (cast, with no rolled seams). The
total length of the borehole casing shall be made up of sections of any standard length, but
minimum length of sections should be 3 m. Casing string must be made of the same type
(diameter, wall thickness, and composition) of casing section for its total depth.
Before proceeding with drilling the contractor must notify the Commission in writing with
dimensions of the chosen casing. Threaded casing joints using BTC (buttress-threaded
connections) are preferred. All threaded joints should be coated with joint compound and
tightened using sufficient torque. A torque of 1000 foot-pounds is recommended. Any casing
that meets these specifications is acceptable.
Immediately prior to cementing, a turbulent flow of clear water and a cleaning solution shall be
circulated down the casing and up the annulus to clean out any mud and debris that is present to
secure a good cement bond. The casing strings shall be supported approximately 5 m (15 feet)
above the bottom of the hole during cementing of the casing.
3.3.4 Cementation and grouting
The Contractor has the flexibility of selecting a preferred cementation method that will
completely bond the casing string to the rock walls over its entire depth with no voids or
shrinkage. For example, cementation can be accomplished through the casing using a cement
shoe and plunger method, cementation can be done via external grout tubes in the annulus
between the casing and host rock where the casing string is sealed by a welded plate at the
bottom. However, the preferred cementation process is to pump cement grout through the
interior of the casing using a plunger and cement shoe and flush the full volume up the annular
space between the exterior casing wall and the rock to the surface. The cement shoe and collar
7

[Page 27]
will form the cement plug at the bottom of the casing. Typical cement grout composition uses
cement, sand, bentonite (clay), water, and an expansive additive to prevent shrinkage upon
drying.
The borehole shall be cemented from bottom to top. The following procedure is recommended.
Cement slurry with sufficient volume to fill the annulus with at least 25% excess shall be
pumped into the casing. Then a latch down plug shall be inserted into the casing and washed
down with clear water. When the plug reaches the baffle, normally 1,000 pounds per square
inch of pressure should force the latching nose of the plug into the baffle and lock it in place.
Once the plug is seated, all pressure must be released to check for zero back-flow, this will
prove that the one-way valves are holding. When zero back-flow is obtained, the cement slurry
shall be allowed to cure for 24 hours under no pressure before performing any activities that
could disturb the bond, such as blowing or bailing the borehole dry of water or proceeding with
the acceptance tests.
After 24 hours, the casing shall be scraped, brushed, and emptied of all fluids and loose solids.
If the cement level drops in the annular space between the pipe and the hole, additional cement
slurry may be added around the casing directly from the surface. The level of the cement grout
in the annular space between the casing and the rock wall must be monitored during the
hardening process. If the level drops, additional cement grout must be added around the casing
from the top using small feed pipes if necessary.
3.3.5 Construction of borehole well-head and enclosure
A concrete pad around the top of the borehole casing (“well-head”) with a thickness of 10 to
20cm and approximately 1m x 1m in area (if square) or approximately 1mdiameter (if circular)
is to be constructed. In addition, a housing or enclosure around the top of the well-head for
protection against the environment shall be built. This enclosure will provide shelter from
water, snow, theft, small animals, etc. A simple inverted “bin” with a rubber or synthetic gasket,
bolted to the concrete pad, will suffice. The pad must include an L- or U-shaped conduit for the
entry of the signal cable that will be protected under the well-head enclosure.
3.3.6 Site remediation
The Contractor will take care of property and removal of debris from the site. Care shall be
taken at all times during the work described in these specifications to prevent undue damage to
the property on which the work is being performed. After completion of the work described in
this specification, the area shall be thoroughly cleaned of all residual material resulting from the
drilling operation or equipment. The surface shall be free of drilling mud, cuttings, scrap
equipment, foliage, packing, and related items. The surface shall be smoothed to its original
contours with all vehicle ruts covered.
3.4 Acceptance tests.
The Contractor will perform a series of acceptance tests as described below.
3.4.1 Verticality Test:
A final verticality test must be performed in the interior of the casing after cementation.
Measurements should be made of the deviation from the vertical at 15 m depth intervals and at
the base of the borehole.

[{"role": "user", "content": "-Goal-
Given a text document that is potentially relevant to this activity and a list of entity types, identify all entities of those types from the text and all relationships among the identified entities.
Use English as output language.

- entity_type: One of the following types: [organization,person,geo,event,category]
- entity_description: Comprehensive description of the entity's attributes and activities
Format each entity as ("entity"<|><entity_name><|><entity_type><|><entity_description>)

2. From the entities identified in step 1, identify all pairs of (source_entity, target_entity) that are *clearly related* to each other.
For each pair of related entities, extract the following information:
- source_entity: name of the source entity, as identified in step 1
- target_entity: name of the target entity, as identified in step 1
- relationship_description: explanation as to why you think the source entity and the target entity are related to each other
- relationship_strength: a numeric score indicating strength of the relationship between the source entity and target entity
- relationship_keywords: one or more high-level key words that summarize the overarching nature of the relationship, focusing on concepts or themes rather than specific details
Format each relationship as ("relationship"<|><source_entity><|><target_entity><|><relationship_description><|><relationship_keywords><|><relationship_strength>)

3. Identify high-level key words that summarize the main concepts, themes, or topics of the entire text. These should capture the overarching ideas present in the document.
Format the content-level key words as ("content_keywords"<|><high_level_keywords>)

4. Return output in English as a single list of all the entities and relationships identified in steps 1 and 2. Use **##** as the list delimiter.

5. When finished, output <|COMPLETE|>

while Alex clenched his jaw, the buzz of frustration dull against the backdrop of Taylor's authoritarian certainty. It was this competitive undercurrent that kept him alert, the sense that his and Jordan's shared commitment to discovery was an unspoken rebellion against Cruz's narrowing vision of control and order.

Then Taylor did something unexpected. They paused beside Jordan and, for a moment, observed the device with something akin to reverence. "If this tech can be understood..." Taylor said, their voice quieter, "It could change the game for us. For all of us."

The underlying dismissal earlier seemed to falter, replaced by a glimpse of reluctant respect for the gravity of what lay in their hands. Jordan looked up, and for a fleeting heartbeat, their eyes locked with Taylor's, a wordless clash of wills softening into an uneasy truce.

It was a small transformation, barely perceptible, but one that Alex noted with an inward nod. They had all been brought here by different paths

[{"role": "user", "content": "-Goal-
Given a text document that is potentially relevant to this activity and a list of entity types, identify all entities of those types from the text and all relationships among the identified entities.
Use English as output language.

-Steps-
1. Identify all entities. For each identified entity, extract the following information:
- entity_name: Name of the entity, use same language as input text. If English, capitalized the name.
- entity_type: One of the following types: [organization,person,geo,event,category]
- entity_description: Comprehensive description of the entity's attributes and activities
Format each entity as ("entity"<|><entity_name><|><entity_type><|><entity_description>)

2. From the entities identified in step 1, identify all pairs of (source_entity, target_entity) that are *clearly related* to each other.
For each pair of related entities, extract the following information:
- source_entity: name of the source entity, as identified in step 1
- target_entity: name of the target entity, as identified in step 1
- relationship_description: explanation as to why you think the source entity and the target entity are related to each other
- relationship_strength: a numeric score indicating strength of the relationship between the source entity and target entity
- relationship_keywords: one or more high-level key words that summarize the overarching nature of the relationship, focusing on concepts or themes rather than specific details
Format each relationship as ("relationship"<|><source_entity><|><target_entity><|><relationship_description><|><relationship_keywords><|><relationship_strength>)

3. Identify high-level key words that summarize the main concepts, themes, or topics of the entire text. These should capture the overarching ideas present in the document.
Format the content-level key words as ("content_keywords"<|><high_level_keywords>)

4. Return output in English as a single list of all the entities and relationships identified in steps 1 and 2. Use **##** as the list delimiter.

5. When finished, output <|COMPLETE|>

######################
-Examples-
######################
Example 1:

Entity_types: [person, technology, mission, organization, location]
Text:
while Alex clenched his jaw, the buzz of frustration dull against the backdrop of Taylor's authoritarian certainty. It was this competitive undercurrent that kept him alert, the sense that his and Jordan's shared commitment to discovery was an unspoken rebellion against Cruz's narrowing vision of control and order.

Then Taylor did something unexpected. They paused beside Jordan and, for a moment, observed the device with something akin to reverence. "If this tech can be understood..." Taylor said, their voice quieter, "It could change the game for us. For all of us."

The underlying dismissal earlier seemed to falter, replaced by a glimpse of reluctant respect for the gravity of what lay in their hands. Jordan looked up, and for a fleeting heartbeat, their eyes locked with Taylor's, a wordless clash of wills softening into an uneasy truce.

It was a small transformation, barely perceptible, but one that Alex noted with an inward nod. They had all been brought here by different paths
################

It was clear that the decisions they made in the ensuing hours could redefine humanity's place in the cosmos or condemn them to ignorance and potential peril.

Their connection to the stars solidified, the group moved to address the crystallizing warning, shifting from passive recipients to active participants. Mercer's latter instincts gained precedence— the team's mandate had evolved, no longer solely to observe and report but to interact and prepare. A metamorphosis had begun, and Operation: Dulce hummed with the newfound frequency of their daring, a tone set not by the earthly

their voice slicing through the buzz of activity. "Control may be an illusion when facing an intelligence that literally writes its own rules," they stated stoically, casting a watchful eye over the flurry of data.

Measurements should be made of the deviation from the vertical at 15 m depth intervals and at

8

[Page 28]
3.4.2 Leak Test:
The final cased and cemented borehole must be checked against leaks by completely filling the
casing with water and recording that the water level has not dropped after 24 hours. The
borehole must then be emptied of water and left completely dry.
3.4.3 Obstruction Test:
A test cylinder of 812 mm length and 95 mm diameter, to be provided by the drilling contractor,
must pass without obstruction to the bottom of the final borehole and then return to the surface.
This should be the final test performed.
3.4.4 Continued Monitoring:
The borehole should be monitored on a weekly basis for at least one month to ensure that it
remains watertight.
3.5 Drilling Report
Within two months after the completion of the drilling, the Contractor will submit the Drilling
Report, providing a full account of the drilling activities, any problems encountered during
drilling and the specifications of the final cased borehole. The Contractor shall provide to the
Commission 2 (two) copies of the Report in English. The report should include the following:
3.5.1 Daily log of Drilling Operations
The log should include details of all operations, including times, a record of the drill bit
diameter used, the lithology or composition of the material being drilled, whether any water
zones or lost-circulation zones are encountered, etc.
3.5.2 Casing Tally
Casing tally showing the length of each section of casing used and the depth-from-surface of
each casing joint.
3.5.3 Results of Acceptance Tests
If verticality measurements were made using a punch-pendulum system (e.g. Totco or
Weatherford Sure-Shot tools), copies of the targets should be provided.
3.5.4 Photo-documentation
Photographs, with descriptive captions, before, during and after the drilling will be provided to
ensure adequate restoration has been performed.
4. Local laws, norms, regulations etc.
The Contractor shall ensure that the work is performed in compliance with any national,
municipal, or local regulations, laws, building codes, licensing, or permitting requirements that
relate to the work to be performed under the Contract.
The Contractor shall also obtain all licenses, permits and/or authorizations needed to carry out
the work under this Contract.
9

[Page 29]
5. Quality and Safety Requirements for the work performed.
The Contractor shall ensure labour safety of personnel at all stages of the work. All
responsibility for compliance with any occupational health and safety and fire safety norms and
laws when carrying out work at the facilities shall be borne by the Contractor. The Work shall
be carried out in compliance with the legislation of the Senegal related to health and safety, as
well as any other legal instruments, building standards and rules, design and construction rules,
sector-specific and cross-sector regulations, approved standard labour protection instructions,
national standards, safety operation rules, national sanitary and epidemiological norms, hygienic
standards.
Compliance with ecological, sanitary, hygienic, fire protection and other rules in force in
Senegal is obligatory.
When carrying out the Work, the Contractor(s) shall ensure safety for its staff, end-user and
third parties, prevent any damage to the Commission’s and the Stations’ property.
6. Inspection
The Commission will carry out inspections any time during the performance of the work.
Specifically, the Commission will visit the site after the completion of all work to be sure that all
Work has been performed in accordance with the Contract.
If the inspection reveals that the work is not in compliance with the Contract, which hinders its
acceptance, the Commission will notify the Contractor about the problem and the remedial
actions to be performed, which shall be remedied by the Contractor to the Commission’s
satisfaction.
The Contractor will provide technical representatives during inspection and facilitate the work
of the Commission’s representatives by providing on-site transportation and other logistical
arrangements as required.

As part of the BBTS station restoration project, the HYDROCONSULTANCE company cleaned the well in order

A 7.5KW power submersible pump with an electrical box.

- Lowering the pump to a depth of 55 m

11/18/2023

- Continued pumping until reaching the bottom of the borehole.
- Demobilization of equipment

7baf55f1f4d79cf0dbf96555d7ce421e.original_prompt:
You are an expert proposal assistant. Generate a comprehensive proposal using ONLY information from these sources:
---Knowledge Base---
{context_data}

---Response Rules---
1. Do NOT use Markdown or special characters like `**`, `#`, or `-`. Use plain text formatting only.
2. Structure the proposal with clear section titles, separated by newlines.
3. NO placeholders like [Company Name]; use real data from the knowledge base or note it as missing if not found.
4. Use a professional tone.

---Proposal Structure---
LETTERHEAD & INTRODUCTION  
- Display brand name, reg/vat numbers, and contact info  
- Greet the recipient briefly and outline purpose  

PROJECT SCOPE  
- Detailed scope from the knowledge base  

EXCLUSIONS  
- List any out-of-scope items if mentioned  

DELIVERABLES  
- Clearly outline what will be delivered  

COMMERCIAL 
- Provide cost breakdown and payment terms in a tabular form  

SCHEDULE  
- Timeline or milestone details  

CONCLUSION & SIGN-OFF  
- Summarize key points  
- Provide sign-off lines referencing Directors or authorized persons  

Current RFQ Requirements: {query}


User Query: "Can you write a proposal that includes:  
    (1) A formal header with the sender's company name, address, email, and phone number, and the recipient's name, position, organization, and address,  
    (2) An introduction that clearly states the purpose of the proposal and introduces the company,  
    (3) A detailed scope of work, breaking it down into specific service categories,  
    (4) A comprehensive pricing breakdown, including cost per service and total project cost, with specified currency and payment terms,  
    (5) A detailed project plan and timeline, outlining key milestones and deliverables,  
    (6) A section on compliance, including adherence to RFQ terms, delivery timelines, insurance coverage, and taxation requirements,  
    (7) A section highlighting the company's experience and qualifications, including past projects, certifications, and key personnel expertise, and  
    (8) A list of all necessary additional documents, such as bidder's statement, vendor profile form, and statement of confirmation."

LETTERHEAD & INTRODUCTION

CDGA Engineering Consultants Ltd  
Reg/VAT Number: Not Available  
Address: Not Available  
Email: procurement@ctbto.org  
Phone Number: +43 (1) 26030-6350  

To: Sally Alvarez de Schreiner  
Chief, Procurement Services Section  
Preparatory Commission for the Comprehensive Nuclear-Test-Ban Treaty Organization (CTBTO)  
Vienna International Centre, P.O. Box 1200, A-1400 Vienna, Austria  

Dear Sally Alvarez de Schreiner,

We are pleased to submit our proposal in response to RFQ No. 2024-108 issued by the Preparatory Commission for the CTBTO. CDGA Engineering Consultants Ltd is eager to offer its services for the drilling and rehabilitation project at the IMS Auxiliary Station in Senegal.

PROJECT SCOPE

The project entails drilling a new borehole and rehabilitating the existing one at the IMS Auxiliary Station. This involves site inspection, drilling, cementation, and borehole testing to meet the specified technical criteria set forth by the Commission.

EXCLUSIONS

The proposal does not cover ancillary support facilities outside the immediate drilling tasks unless explicitly listed in the RFQ's terms.

DELIVERABLES

1. Drilling of a new borehole according to LOT 2 specifications.
2. Rehabilitation of the existing borehole as per LOT 1, including cleaning and testing.
3. Submission of detailed Drilling Reports, including daily logs, photo documentation, and test results.

COMMERCIAL

| Service Description                      | Cost per Unit (EURO) | Total Cost (EURO) |
|------------------------------------------|----------------------|-------------------|
| Drilling a new borehole                  | Cost Not Available   | Total Cost Not Available   |
| Rehabilitating the existing borehole     | Cost Not Available   | Total Cost Not Available   |

Payment Terms: Payment to be made within 30 days of receipt and acceptance of the goods/services and of the following documents: Invoice(s) showing the firm fixed price.

SCHEDULE

The project is expected to commence upon acceptance of our proposal with an anticipated completion within ninety (90) days. Key milestones include:

- Week 1-2: Site preparations and logistics setup
- Week 3-4: Borehole drilling commencement
- Week 5-7: Cementation process and initial tests
- Week 8-9: Rehabilitation of the existing borehole
- Week 10-12: Final testing and report submission

COMPLIANCE

The project will be executed following the RFQ terms, including adherence to delivery timelines, comprehensive insurance coverage from shipment to delivery, and strict compliance with tax exemption regulations as outlined by the Commission.

COMPANY EXPERIENCE AND QUALIFICATIONS

CDGA Engineering Consultants Ltd has extensive experience in power systems and infrastructure projects with organizations such as the CTBTO, PepsiCo, TANESCO, and UN missions. Our technical team led by Pat Moriarty, a Chartered Electrical Engineer, has managed international projects ensuring compliance with global standards and local laws.

ADDITIONAL DOCUMENTS

- Bidder's Statement
- Vendor Profile Form
- Statement of Confirmation

CONCLUSION & SIGN-OFF

We appreciate the opportunity to present this proposal and are confident that our team possesses the expertise to deliver successful outcomes for your project. Should you require any further information or clarification, please do not hesitate to contact us.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature Line for Pat Moriarty]  
Pat Moriarty  
Technical Director, CDGA Engineering Consultants Ltd
